section.para: The data are gathered within the TERENO (Terrestrial Environmental Observatories) long-term research programme involving several Helmholtz Association Centers in Germany (www.tereno.net). TERENO aims to catalogue the longterm ecological, social and economic impact of global change at regional and landscape level. The biodiversity part of TERENO deals with monitoring and research on different organism groups: (1) Vascular plants (primary producers, overall biodiversity indicators), (2) Bees and Hoverflies (important pollinators; ecosystem service agents), (3) Butterflies (indicators for habitat quality, pollinators), (4) Birds (highly mobile, sensitive to landscape context, integrative at landscape scale).This dataset covers data about bees trapped within 4x4 km landscapes in Saxony-Anhalt (Germany) dominated by agricultural use. The trapping is done with combined flight traps (combination of yellow pan trap and transparent perspexes) placed at ecotones (transition zone between arable fields and semi-natural habitats) in May-June and August-September each year.

para.literalLayout: One trap / km² is placed at the border (ecotone) between semi-natural habitat and arable field (16 traps / site of 4x4 km). Traps consist of a yellow funnel (diameter: 25 cm) and two crossed perspex windows on top of the funnel. Trapped insects will fall in the funnel which is filled with water containing a preservative (Parmetol K 40; 0.5%). Traps are installed with a wooden frame at a height of about one m above ground. Operating schedule (emptying interval 14 days): Start at week 2–7 after full bloom of Taraxacum officinale (phenological indicator), usually in our region end of April or beginning of May; 4x emptying until end of June, then stop for 6 weeks and start again until end of September. Insects are sorted in the laboratory and sent to a specialist for determination. Frequency: yearly

methodStep.instrumentation: Yellow funnels, perspexes and wooden frames (trap material needs to be organized individually)
